Diagnosis of Erectile Dysfunction (ED)
At UT Physicians Urology, our team of experts will work with you to diagnose and treat your erectile dysfunction (ED). To determine the cause of your ED, we typically use a combination of medical history, physical exam, testing, and imaging.
During your initial appointment, our doctor will ask you questions about your symptoms, your medical history, and your current medications. We may also perform a physical exam to assess your circulation, reflexes, and sensation.
Depending on your symptoms and medical history, additional testing may be recommended to help diagnose your ED. These tests may include:
Vascular studies: These tests assess the circulation in your penis and can help determine if there are any blood flow issues contributing to your ED.
Rigidity and sensation testing: Our doctors will examine your penile sensation and rigidity to help identify any nerve or muscle problems that may be contributing to your ED.
Medication response testing: This test involves taking medications called PDE5 inhibitors, such as sildenafil (Viagra), tadalafil (Cialis), or vardenafil (Levitra), to see if they improve your ability to achieve or maintain an erection.
Ultrasound: This non-invasive test uses sound waves to create images of the inside of your penis and help identify any structural issues that may be contributing to your ED.
Treatment for ED depends on the underlying cause. Our team of experts will work with you to develop a personalized treatment plan that may include:
Lifestyle changes, such as quitting smoking and increasing exercise
Medications, such as PDE5 inhibitors, if needed
Vacuum constriction devices
Transurethral injection therapy

I’m delighted to bring you the first in a series of five blog posts about the early days of The Cock and Bull Story, the unique project where I’m bringing together four talented creatives to collaboratively write – and design – short stories for a unique, limited edition book.
In this post, we’ll delve into the origins of the project and hear from our talented team of writers, Tanya Byrne, Hannah Jane Walker, Emma Sheppard and Charlotte Eccles.
The Cock and Bull Story: Part One
It all started with a conversation over a bottle of wine, where my good friend and fellow book lover, Lisa Jenson (a graphic designer and illustrator) and I discussed collaborative projects and our mutual admiration for the great short story anthologies of the past.
As we toasted to a beautiful friendship, we decided to bring together our talents and create a new project that would celebrate the art of short stories and push the boundaries of creativity.
And so, The Cock and Bull Story was born.
The idea was this: write short stories that would be the perfect accompaniment to a beautifully designed book, and design the book in a way that would enhance the stories. We wanted to create a unique book for readers to cherish, collect and enjoy – something that was more than just a collection of stories.
And so, we brought together four talented creatives to join forces on this exciting project. Writers Tanya Byrne, Hannah Jane Walker, Emma Sheppard and Charlotte Eccles would each contribute their own short stories, all with a common thread. The stories would be linked by the setting of The Cock & Bull pub, a cozy spot nestled in a country village, where the regulars gather to tell tales of love, loss, hope and forgiveness.
For the next four posts, we’ll explore each step of the storytelling journey – from the first drafts of the short stories to the final design of the book. We’ll share insights and anecdotes from our team and give you a front-row seat to the creative process.

In the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina, amidst the chaos and destruction that followed, one community banded together in the face of tragedy: the New Orleans Saints football team. Drawing inspiration from the Crescent City's unique culture and spirit, Jeffrey Aaron Smith tells the story of the Saints' unprecedented season, and the role they played in the rebuilding of their city.
From the team's first game in the Superdome, a symbol of their city's struggle, to the emotional home game against the Atlanta Falcons, when a banner was unveiled to commemorate the New Orleans community, Smith captures the passion and resilience of the Saints and their fans. He also delves into the behind-the-scenes stories of the players and coaches, as well as the unique challenges they faced, both on and off the field.
An ode to the power of football to bring people together and heal a city, Saints at the Gate is a riveting account of one of the most unforgettable seasons in NFL history. It is a tribute to the indomitable spirit of New Orleans and a celebration of the unwavering determination of the Saints, who, in the face of adversity, managed to triumph on and off the field.

The Great Gig in the Sky is a song by the English rock band Pink Floyd. It appears on their 1973 album The Dark Side of the Moon. The lyrics were written by frontman Roger Waters and are sung by the female vocalist Clare Torry. In 2004, Q magazine named The Great Gig in the Sky the 44th greatest song of all time. In a poll of Radio 2 listeners, it was named the greatest piece of music of all time.

Not wrong. It' In his classic book on the history of philosophy, Bertrand Russell famously identified three major factors contributing to the decline and fall of civilizations. According to Russell, these factors are (1) the growth of bureaucracy, (2) economic decline, and (3) the growth of military establishments. Each of these factors, he believed, can be seen in the decline and fall of ancient empires such as Rome.

Russell argued that the growth of bureaucracy contributes to the decline of civility because it is often accompanied by an increase in rigidity and rigor that stifles innovation and creativity. Bureaucracies, he said, are "characterized by a complex network of rules, regulations, and administrative procedures that are used to ensure the efficiency and effectiveness of an organization." These rules and regulations, however, can also stifle creativity and innovation, as the "rules become the ends rather than the means to a rational organization."

Similarly, Russell believed that economic decline can contribute to the decline of civilizations because it often leads to a decline in the material well-being of the people and a corresponding rise in social unrest. Economic decline can also lead to a decline in the quality of life for individuals, as they struggle to make ends meet and meet their basic needs.

Finally, Russell argued that the growth of military establishments can be a major contributing factor to the decline and fall of civilizations. He noted that military establishments often require vast resources to maintain, and that these resources can be diverted from other areas of society that are important for the well-being of individuals and communities. Military establishments can also contribute to the development of a culture of aggression and violence that can undermine social cohesion and promote conflict within and among societies.

Russell argued that these factors are not the only causes of the decline and fall of civilizations, but that they are significant contributing factors. He believed that the rise and fall of civilizations is a complex and multifaceted process that is shaped by a variety of political, economic, social, and cultural factors.
